summary.p: A syllabary and a grammar of the Malayalam language entitled Grammaire de la Langue Malabare on a sheet of paper pasted on the front guard leaf.

The work is not divided in numbered chapters. However nine sections can be identified on the basis of titles and arguments, as listed below:
Regles Generalles pour les noms. Nouns are inflected into five declensions (pp. 1-11).
Pronoms, i.e. personnels, possessifs, demonstatifs, relatifs, interrogatifs, indefinis, responsifs, affirmatifs et negatifs (pp. 12-22).
Noms des nombre, i.e. cardinal, adverbe (pp. 23-28). This section also includes: Grand Livret de Multiplication (pp. 29-41); Quarré de Pythagore, en Chiffres Mallabars (p. 42).
Adjectif (pp. 43-46); Genre (pp. 46-48); Comparatif (pp. 48-49).
Conjugaison des Verbes (pp. 49-91). Apart from moods and tenses (i.e. Indicatif, Subjonctif, Optatif, Infinitif, Gerundif, Participe, Conditionnel, Imperative, Supin, présent, imparfait, preterit parfait, passé eloigné, anterieur, plus que parfait, futuro, passé avenir), this section also includes: Verbe Personnel, Verbes Effectifs et mandatifs, Verbes deffectifs affirmatif, Verbes negatifs, Particule qui rendent les verbes affirmatifs negatifs, Verbes de l'Elegance Mallabarre. The section on verbs ends with Maniere d'user des Verbes, et quand on doit s'en servir (pp. 92-96).
Propositions (i.e. de lieu, de temp, de maniere, qui gouvernent le Genitif, le Datif, l'accusatif, etc.) (pp. 96-102).
Conjonction (pp. 102-104).
Interjection (pp. 104-105).
Syntaxe ou maniere de connoitre toutes les parties d'un discours (pp. 105-114).
Description by Cristina Muru based on the digital images available on Gallica.

Red circle containing an eagle and the writing Bibliothèque Impérial MSS (folio 1r). This is the stamp in use from 1852 to 1870 (cf. stamp no. 36 in Josserand and Bruno 1960: 282). It is placed in the middle of the page.

binding.p: The stiff boards and spine is covered with paper that is folded over the edges of the boards and glued down. Hence, pastedowns are applied to conceal this mechanism.

origin.origDate: No internal date. According to Vinson, it probably dates to the beginning of the 19th century (see Petit 2014, p. 450). The suggested span of time 1750-1782 is calculated on the basis of the sojourn of Bernard François Bertrand Picot, marquis de la Motte (1734-1797), in India. Picot reached the Malabar Coast in 1750 and was named General Commander of the Malabar Coast and Governor of Mahé in 1751. He returned in France in 1782 (Courcelle 1823, pp. 370-371). The linguistic features of the variety of the Portuguese language used in the manuscript would allow to date it earlier, in the first half of the 17th century.
